thread.title: De Pere completes perfect season in FRCC
thread.title_full: De Pere completes perfect season in FRCC

title: De Pere completes perfect season in FRCC
text:
De Pere completes perfect season in FRCC Redbirds win first conference title since 2007 Post to Facebook De Pere completes perfect season in FRCC Redbirds win first conference title since 2007 Check out this story on greenbaypressgazette.com: http://gbpg.net/1LyYZrn Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation Scott Venci, Press-Gazette Media 10:53 p.m. CDT October 16, 2015 De Pere running back Nik Ohuafi (33) gets away from Bay Port defensive back Jake Stelzer (18) to score a touchdown Friday night at Bay Port. The Redbirds concluded a perfect regular season and clinched the FRCC title with the win. (Photo: Evan Siegle/Press-Gazette Media) 
SUAMICO — The De Pere football team found the secret to success in the Fox River Classic Conference. 
His name is Cole Runge. 
The senior quarterback led the Redbirds to a 26-7 win over Bay Port on Friday night, clinching the outright conference title and completing a perfect regular season. 
The win continued what started in Week 3 last season, when Runge took over at quarterback for an injured Emmett Kulick. 
He has gone 16-0 in the regular season since, leading the Redbirds to their first conference championship since 2007 and likely helping to deliver them a No. 1 seed for the WIAA Division 2 playoffs when brackets are released on Saturday. 
De Pere (9-0) often found a way to beat the weaker teams in the FRCC during Chad Michalkiewicz’s first few seasons as coach, but it could never beat a good one. 
This year, they beat every single one of them. 
“I’m so proud,” Michalkiewicz said. “You come in with a vision, weight room expectations, offseason 7-on-7 in the summer. These guys answered the bell. Community service, in the classroom, it’s no mistake these guys are champions. They will be champions the rest of their life.” 
Runge, meanwhile, would be the first to point out that De Pere isn’t just his team, which was evident against a Pirates squad that had been 19-0 in true home games in Bay Port coach Gary Westerman’s first four seasons. 
It also was the first time any FRCC team coached by Westerman lost at home, including the one season he spent at Pulaski in 2011. 
While Runge scored two rushing touchdowns, senior running back Nik Ohuafi continued a dominating season by rushing 42 times for 232 yards. 
He started the year at his customary defensive end position, only to be moved to running back after early-season injuries. This performance, which also included a 10-yard TD pass to Zack Rabas to close out the scoring in the fourth quarter, only helped his FRCC player of the year candidacy. He finished as the league’s rushing champion with 1,639 yards. 
Ohuafi put De Pere up 6-0 in the final seconds of the first quarter on a 14-yard touchdown run, which capped a 13-play drive in which every play was either a run by Ohuafi or Runge. 
Runge took his turn in the final seconds of the second quarter after Bay Port missed a 36-yard field goal attempt earlier, running around the left end for an 8-yard TD and then completing a pass to tight end Max Huddleston for a 2-point conversion and a 14-0 lead. 
The score was set up thanks to an interception by De Pere defensive back Connor Kupsh, who jumped a route and picked off a Quinn Pierner pass attempt at the Bay Port 34. 
That came just two plays after a big hit by Bay Port defensive back Jake Weber forced an Ohuafi fumble to give the Pirates the ball. 
“We had a bunch of mistakes early,” Westerman said. “We had the ball down on the 20 or 15, and we get a holding penalty. Went to kick a field goal and it was long. We moved the ball, and then we had a turnover. 
“We just struggled to get consistency and we made too many mistakes to score.” 
De Pere added to its lead with 2 minutes, 46 seconds left in the third quarter on a 1-yard TD run by Runge that made it 20-0. 
Bay Port (7-2) finally got something going with backup quarterback Brett Frieder, who replaced Pierner in the second half. 
Frieder completed a 35-yard pass to the De Pere 1 on his second drive, before Evan Bindas scored on a TD run with 1:33 remaining in the third. 
It would be as close as the Pirates would get, because they hardly got the ball back. 
De Pere started a possession with 10:05 left, and took the next 7:30 off the clock on a 16-play 65-yard drive that featured two fourth down conversions and ended with the TD pass from Ohuafi. 
Game over. 
De Pere will now prepare for what it hopes is a strong postseason run led in part by a quarterback who almost never loses. 
“If you have got guys like the guys we have, I don’t know, I feel like it was possible,” Runge said of his team’s impressive regular-season winning streak. “The way we came together last season, that translated so well this year. 
“We have got a team that just never quits.” 
De Pere 6 8 6 6 – 26 
Bay Port 0 0 7 0 – 7 
First quarter 
DP: Nik Ohuafi 14 run (run failed). 
Second quarter 
DP: Cole Runge 6 run (Max Huddleston catch). 
Third quarter 
DP: Runge 1 run (run failed) 
BP: Evan Bindas 1 run (Josh Jennerjohn kick). 
Fourth quarter 
DP: Zack Rabas 10 pass from Ohuafi (run failed). 
Rushing – BP: Pierner 13-36; DP: Ohuafi 42-232. 
Passing – BP: Pierner 3-11-69. DP: Runge 3-6-26. 
Receiving – BP: Connor Sullivan 3-69; DP: Rabas 3-24. 48 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://gbpg.net/1LyYZrn TOP VIDEOS
